articles.title: SJAA ephemeris APR '80
articles.summary: This document, the SJAA ephemeris for April '80, details a packed schedule of events for the San Jose Astronomical Association in April and May 1980. It lists board meetings, indoor and outdoor star parties, observing sessions for National Astronomy Day, new and full moon dates, and mentions the Riverside Telescope Makers' Conference. Additionally, the bulletin announces the establishment of the Dr. A.B. Gregory annual award, encouraging nominations for members who have made outstanding contributions to amateur astronomy.

articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: SJAA members successfully completed an African solar eclipse tour, observing wildlife and the eclipse despite some cloud cover. The article announces upcoming Astronomy Day events, encourages member participation, and details club matters such as membership renewals, board changes, and the importance of proper conduct and site agreements for observing at Fremont Peak. It also includes a table of Great Red Spot transit times for Jupiter.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: The article provides an update on comet activity, noting no new discoveries or recoveries this year and the fading of Comet Bradfield (1979L) to 12th magnitude. It anticipates the return of three periodic comets—Encke, Tuttle, and Stephan-Oterma—by year-end, with Encke expected to reach magnitude 8. Additionally, the piece highlights historical comet discoverer Caroline Herschel and recent binocular discoverer David Seargent.

articles.title: PHOTOGRAPH THE MOON & PLANETS
articles.summary: This article by Bob Fingerhut serves as a comprehensive guide to photographing the Moon and planets using the eyepiece projection technique. It outlines necessary equipment, provides mathematical formulas for calculating effective focal length, magnification, and focal ratio, and offers recommended starting exposure settings for the Moon, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn. Additionally, it advises on film selection, photo processing, and the use of colored filters to enhance planetary features.

articles.title: MURPHY'S LAWS for AMATEUR ASTRONOMY (thanks to Shea Pratt)
articles.summary: This document outlines a humorous collection of "Murphy's Laws" specifically tailored for amateur astronomy, detailing common frustrations and ironic mishaps encountered by enthusiasts. It covers everything from adverse weather conditions during important astronomical events and equipment malfunctions to challenges with astrophotography and star party logistics. The laws highlight the often unpredictable and challenging nature of the hobby, presented with a comedic tone.
